section.heading: Argument of Thomas W. Jamison, III

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: - 490, John L. Brady, petitioner versus Maryland.
Mr. Jamison, you may continue your argument.

turn.speaker: thomas_w_jamison_iii
turn.label: Mr. Thomas W. Jamison, III
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court.
Yesterday before the recess, I had sought to establish two facts which I believe must be considered during the study of this case.
First of all, the statement of the confederate, Boblit, contains nothing, which would exculpate Brady from guilt of first-degree murder under the Maryland felony murder statute.

It merely contains the assertion or the admission that Boblit himself actually strangled the victim, but it places Brady at the scene of the crime as the man who knew Brooks, as the man who said, “We have got to kill Brooks,” as the man who said “We've have got to strangle Brooks.”
Secondly, the attorney representing John Brady determined before the trial even began that the real issue in the trial was not guilt or innocence, but penalty for murder in the first-degree.
In other words, he sought to persuade the jury to bring in a verdict of guilty of first-degree murder without capital punishment.

Now, at the trial of the case, Brady took the stand and again Brady admitted as he had in his statements, which he had given to the police prior to his trial, he again admitted he had participated in the robbery, but denied he had actually committed the homicide.
In his --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Mr. Jamison what happens in Maryland if a man pleads guilty to the first-degree murder or doesn't that really happen?

turn.speaker: thomas_w_jamison_iii
turn.label: Mr. Thomas W. Jamison, III
turn.text: Mr. Justice Stewart, if a man pleads guilty to first-degree murder then the court would have the option as to whether or not to sentence him to death or to sentence him to life imprisonment.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And he doesn't get a jury trial on that punishment?

turn.speaker: thomas_w_jamison_iii
turn.label: Mr. Thomas W. Jamison, III
turn.text: He would not have a jury trial.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: This is a function of a single judge, is that it?

turn.speaker: thomas_w_jamison_iii
turn.label: Mr. Thomas W. Jamison, III
turn.text: That's correct Your Honor, it's merely a question of sentence.
The closing argument or at least the -- the closing argument to the jury by a counsel for Brady consisted of a confession of guilt of first-degree murder.
Now when Brady again went to court himself to testify at the post-conviction hearing before the Circuit Court for Anne Arundel County, he again admitted his guilt of first degree murder.
He admitted that he was there and he participated in the robbery.
He admitted the facts which constitute first-degree murder on the statute.
So --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And also that the murder was committed at the time of the robbery, not later, is that correct, because I did notice some place along the line here where it was contended that the murder was detached from the robbery itself?

turn.speaker: thomas_w_jamison_iii
turn.label: Mr. Thomas W. Jamison, III
turn.text: I believe Mr. Chief Justice that point was raised in Brady's appeal from his conviction.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But not at the trial, I think you answered that yesterday?

turn.speaker: thomas_w_jamison_iii
turn.label: Mr. Thomas W. Jamison, III
turn.text: I stand corrected Mr. Chief Justice, Mr. Bamberger reminds me of Boblit's appeal that actually raised that point.
They were tried -- they were argued together, the two appeals were tried under one argument.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I see and Brady did not raise it at all?

turn.speaker: thomas_w_jamison_iii
turn.label: Mr. Thomas W. Jamison, III
turn.text: Apparently not Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: thomas_w_jamison_iii
turn.label: Mr. Thomas W. Jamison, III
turn.text: But at any rate this point was brought up at the post-conviction hearing.

Now throughout the other proceedings in this case, it had never been controverted that Brady has always admitted his presence at the trial -- at the robbery and his participation in the robbery and I think it is also important to remember that there was a judicial confession in effect at his trial when Brady admitted his presence and his participation.

Now, in view of these facts and the fact that the Court of Appeals in its opinion states that nothing in -- well, this withheld confession this appears on page 52 of the record, nothing in it could have reduced the appellant Brady's offense below murder in the first degree.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: May, I ask you just one more thing before you get into another phase of the case?
On page 26, item 25 that we talked about yesterday somewhat, would you mind telling me when that statement was made by counsel for the defendant and in want context please?

turn.speaker: thomas_w_jamison_iii
turn.label: Mr. Thomas W. Jamison, III
turn.text: It was made prior to the trial at a conference in the judge's chambers with counsel for a coconspirator or the confederate and they were discussing various aspects such as we have a jury trial, which defendant will be tried first and so forth and at that time, Counsel for Brady said that his trial would be limited to penalty for murder in the first-degree.
Now, in Maryland, the Constitution provides that the jury is the judge of the law as well as the facts.

This provision has been in the Constitution of Maryland at least since 1867 I think and to my knowledge has never been applied in exactly the way it is sought to be applied in this case, but the Court of Appeals of Maryland in a recent case, Giles versus State said this.
“It is the duty of a jury to decide a case according to the established rules of law.”

In all frankness, I must admit that this statement was made from the other side of the coin, dealing the duty of the jury from the standpoint of the defendant other than the standpoint of the State, but I respectfully submit that the duty of the jury is the same whether it acquits the defendant or convicts him, it is nevertheless the duty of a jury to decide the case according to the established rules of the law, in spite of this constitutional provision.
Otherwise, we would have nothing but chaos.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: [Inaudible]

turn.speaker: thomas_w_jamison_iii
turn.label: Mr. Thomas W. Jamison, III
turn.text: Mr. Justice Brennan, it is the State of Maryland's position that the trial judge charge was an error that he went further than the law required.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: [Inaudible]

turn.speaker: thomas_w_jamison_iii
turn.label: Mr. Thomas W. Jamison, III
turn.text: No prep just whatsoever.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: [Inaudible]

turn.speaker: thomas_w_jamison_iii
turn.label: Mr. Thomas W. Jamison, III
turn.text: Yes Your Honor.
That's exactly what they said, I think in their opinions, what they held in their opinion.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: [Inaudible]

turn.speaker: thomas_w_jamison_iii
turn.label: Mr. Thomas W. Jamison, III
turn.text: Giles was decided after this case and I might say that the Giles case, there is a petition for certiorari pending at the present time.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: [Inaudible]

turn.speaker: thomas_w_jamison_iii
turn.label: Mr. Thomas W. Jamison, III
turn.text: You do.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I don't quite understand, you say that the Constitution says one thing and the law says another.

turn.speaker: thomas_w_jamison_iii
turn.label: Mr. Thomas W. Jamison, III
turn.text: No, Mr. Justice Black.
I'm saying that the Court of Appeals has said that it is the duty of a jury to decide a case according to the established rules of law.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But what does the Constitution say?

turn.speaker: thomas_w_jamison_iii
turn.label: Mr. Thomas W. Jamison, III
turn.text: The Constitution says, the jury is the judge of the law as one of the fact.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, do you think that Constitution is unconstitutional?

turn.speaker: thomas_w_jamison_iii
turn.label: Mr. Thomas W. Jamison, III
turn.text: No, I do not.

What I'm saying though is that although the jury has the right to decide the law, they have the duty to decide the law according to their conscience, according to reason, according to their best efforts and not according to some whim or fancy.

They have the same duty to decide the law as the trial judge would have to interpret the law according to their best ability and not to ignore the law, or disregard the law, or twist the law for some purpose or other.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: What purpose – what effect it would give it to the provision of the Constitution?
[Inaudible]

turn.speaker: thomas_w_jamison_iii
turn.label: Mr. Thomas W. Jamison, III
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Is that into your Constitution?
[Inaudible] something duty of the jury, power of the jury to go beyond what it already had [Inaudible]

turn.speaker: thomas_w_jamison_iii
turn.label: Mr. Thomas W. Jamison, III
turn.text: It is my opinion that it adds very little to the power of a jury or to the -- what it would ordinarily be the case in other jurisdictions. It maybe that when the constitutional prevision was enacted, the idea was to give a great scope of authority to the jury, but I believe that in view of the two recent cases, the Giles case and the Brady case, the Court of Appeals has indicated that it feels there was a very limited scope to this provision.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well what you in effect saying is that they have changed your Constitution, isn't it?

turn.speaker: thomas_w_jamison_iii
turn.label: Mr. Thomas W. Jamison, III
turn.text: They have construed the Constitution, that all.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: It seemed to mean contrary to what it seems to mean on its face?

turn.speaker: thomas_w_jamison_iii
turn.label: Mr. Thomas W. Jamison, III
turn.text: I don't believe that is correct.
I think the jury has the right to interpret the law and if it makes a mistake no one can again say it.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: [Inaudible]

turn.speaker: thomas_w_jamison_iii
turn.label: Mr. Thomas W. Jamison, III
turn.text: I think that is the law, now it's true --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well another thing to find out is that if we ought to go on the basis of your argument that the Constitution said, that it means what it says, that means now, has a less restricted meaning by reason of the recent opinion of the Court?

turn.speaker: thomas_w_jamison_iii
turn.label: Mr. Thomas W. Jamison, III
turn.text: Yes I believe that is my position.
I believe that the Court of Appeals has indicated in the Giles case that the constitutional provision is not as broad as it might be thought to be upon reading it.
I think that the jury has a duty to construe the law the same as a judge would construe a law, it was best of its ability and not whimsically.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: [Inaudible]

turn.speaker: thomas_w_jamison_iii
turn.label: Mr. Thomas W. Jamison, III
turn.text: There has been an effort Mr. Justice Harlan, I believe that the current session of the legislature, such a measure was introduced and it was not enacted, I don't know whether its been defeated or whether it's still pending, but I think there was one enacted, I mean introduced.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: [Inaudible]

turn.speaker: thomas_w_jamison_iii
turn.label: Mr. Thomas W. Jamison, III
turn.text: I honestly don't know whether there have been others or not.

turn.speaker: arthur_j_goldberg
turn.label: Justice Arthur J. Goldberg
turn.text: [Inaudible]

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well stated bluntly, as I understand it, you are saying the recent rule that the jury is not a judge of the law in fact in Maryland, although the Constitution says it is?

turn.speaker: thomas_w_jamison_iii
turn.label: Mr. Thomas W. Jamison, III
turn.text: No Mr. Justice Black, I don't say that.
I'm merely saying that there is not the distinction between the situation in Maryland and situation in other states which would appear on the face of the Maryland Constitution.
The jury is the judge of the law, but they have a duty to judge the law conscientiously in good faith, sincerely and legitimately and not whimsically, and if they do --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What's the remedy if they do not?

turn.speaker: thomas_w_jamison_iii
turn.label: Mr. Thomas W. Jamison, III
turn.text: We have no remedy.
If they act according to whim and caprice and acquit the defendant, the defendant is acquitted, and there is no remedy.
They have the power --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Same as the general verdict?

turn.speaker: thomas_w_jamison_iii
turn.label: Mr. Thomas W. Jamison, III
turn.text: That is correct.
So they have the power to do this and that cannot be denied, but any jury has the power to do this.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: But in a case of jury where it is operating under [Inaudible] constitutional provision, there is a presumption [Inaudible]

turn.speaker: thomas_w_jamison_iii
turn.label: Mr. Thomas W. Jamison, III
turn.text: I don't think that there is such a presumption under the Maryland law.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: No, but isn't the [Inaudible] I gather they don't have to be the judge of the law for judgment.
It may be that they were [Inaudible]

turn.speaker: thomas_w_jamison_iii
turn.label: Mr. Thomas W. Jamison, III
turn.text: They do not, that is correct.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You are saying that [Inaudible]

turn.speaker: thomas_w_jamison_iii
turn.label: Mr. Thomas W. Jamison, III
turn.text: That is our position exactly.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: [Inaudible]

turn.speaker: thomas_w_jamison_iii
turn.label: Mr. Thomas W. Jamison, III
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You are saying that the Court of Appeals can tell the jury what the law is, but they can't decide what the law is, for themselves.

turn.speaker: thomas_w_jamison_iii
turn.label: Mr. Thomas W. Jamison, III
turn.text: I'm saying that they have --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Maybe that's right, but I'm just -- if we have to decide this, I would want very, very, very clear reason myself for saying if the Constitution of Maryland says that the jury shall be the judge of the law and in fact that can be escaped by saying, the judge can be the judge of the law, in fact he can get it covered and that's the law they have to follow, not their own.

turn.speaker: thomas_w_jamison_iii
turn.label: Mr. Thomas W. Jamison, III
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That you need to follow.
You were saying if you are drawing a distinction between that duty and what can do under the constitutional provision.
Do you have that same thing with reference to liable in Maryland?

turn.speaker: thomas_w_jamison_iii
turn.label: Mr. Thomas W. Jamison, III
turn.text: To liable?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Yeah, same provision.

turn.speaker: thomas_w_jamison_iii
turn.label: Mr. Thomas W. Jamison, III
turn.text: I honestly don't know Mr. Justice Black.
I'm not familiar with laws of Maryland pertaining to liable.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Many states have that and why they've had there I don't understand it, but it remained the law.
It's always been held, they didn't have to follow the judge at all, when they have the duty do it.
They can decide as they saw fit.
I think [Inaudible], I'm not sure.

turn.speaker: thomas_w_jamison_iii
turn.label: Mr. Thomas W. Jamison, III
turn.text: I can't help you on that point.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Jamison is it customary in Maryland in cases of this kind to instruct -- for the judge when he instructs the jury to tell them that his instructions are only advisory and they may decide the law in anyway that they desire.

turn.speaker: thomas_w_jamison_iii
turn.label: Mr. Thomas W. Jamison, III
turn.text: Yes, Mr. Chief Justice, it not only is customary, but I think it's mandatory.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well how do you reconcile that with what you just argued to us?

turn.speaker: thomas_w_jamison_iii
turn.label: Mr. Thomas W. Jamison, III
turn.text: Well I'm afraid I'm not getting my point really across as well I would like.
It's a very thin distinction, I admit, but the jury does have the right under the constitution to interpret the law, to find the law if you like.

All I'm saying is they've got to do it honestly, conscientiously, intelligently to the -- according to their best efforts and they cannot do it according to whim and if they do it according to the whim, then they are violating their duty to the state, to the people.
Now if they do that, if they violate their duty there is no way that anybody can do anything about it.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: [Inaudible]accept it the way it should –-

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Aren't you confusing power and duty?

turn.speaker: thomas_w_jamison_iii
turn.label: Mr. Thomas W. Jamison, III
turn.text: I don't believe I am.
I think I am merely relying upon what the Court of Appeals has said in the Giles case.
And although they said it there in reference to the duty of the jury that it owes to the defendant.
I think the same duty is owed to the state.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: [Inaudible]

turn.speaker: thomas_w_jamison_iii
turn.label: Mr. Thomas W. Jamison, III
turn.text: That is exactly our position.
That no jury acting in good faith could possibly under the facts of this peculiar case, could possibly have rendered any verdict except guilty of first degree murder or not guilty of anything at all.
But since there was a judicial confession in Court by the defendant, the jury really could not bring in a verdict of not guilty.

However, the Court -- the trial judge was entitled at the trial to instruct the jury that they could bring in a verdict of guilty of first degree murder, guilty of first degree murder without capital punishment or not guilty.

On the facts of the record as it stands now however, in view of all the facts and the way in which the trial was conducted, it is our position that the defendant was not denied due process of law by being given a new trial on the issue of punishment only.
Since this is the sole point to which his claim of prejudice relates.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Well I think you said yesterday that this confession [Inaudible]

turn.speaker: thomas_w_jamison_iii
turn.label: Mr. Thomas W. Jamison, III
turn.text: It would have been, that is correct.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: And that is not getting [Inaudible] would have done had the government said these people what the court had said they should have done and [Inaudible]

turn.speaker: thomas_w_jamison_iii
turn.label: Mr. Thomas W. Jamison, III
turn.text: There is no doubt about the fact that he is not -- now he had not had this confession or this statement of Boblit before a jury before he was tried.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2

turn.text: And he would have it if the state had not done what it did [Inaudible] if it had not been done, he would have had [Inaudible] at his trail [Inaudible]

turn.speaker: thomas_w_jamison_iii
turn.label: Mr. Thomas W. Jamison, III
turn.text: This is correct.
Our position on that is this, that there was no prejudice, because there is nothing in the statement which could have reduced the offense below first degree murder.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: [Inaudible] jury found murder it seems to me the typical case where the jury is going to exercise their power under the law [Inaudible]

turn.speaker: thomas_w_jamison_iii
turn.label: Mr. Thomas W. Jamison, III
turn.text: But there is nothing in the statement which could possibly lead the jury to believe he was as an innocent bystander.
The statement says that it was Brady's idea to kill him.
It was Brady's idea to strangle him.
Now --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And wanted to shoot him and Brady wanted to strangle him.

turn.speaker: thomas_w_jamison_iii
turn.label: Mr. Thomas W. Jamison, III

So the jury couldn't possibly get any sympathy for the man out of this statement.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: [Inaudible]

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: [Inaudible] not to say it is harmless error?

turn.speaker: thomas_w_jamison_iii
turn.label: Mr. Thomas W. Jamison, III
turn.text: I think it was harmless error from the standpoint of guilt or innocence, but not from the standpoint of punishment.
It might have persuaded the jury to recommend without capital punishment, and that is exactly the relief that he has been granted by the Court of Appeals.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: The vagaries of a jury's reasoning are beyond human understanding when you begin to try to hold that something would have been -- would have done him no good [Inaudible], but it is difficult.

turn.speaker: thomas_w_jamison_iii
turn.label: Mr. Thomas W. Jamison, III
turn.text: Yes it is difficult.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart

turn.speaker: thomas_w_jamison_iii
turn.label: Mr. Thomas W. Jamison, III
turn.text: No Mr. Justice Stewart, if the jury in Maryland does not rule on the constitutionality of a statute, it does not rule on the admissibility of evidence and in the first instance it does not rule on the voluntariness of a confession, although after the judge plans a confession to be voluntary, then the jury in turn is on the point.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: [Inaudible]

turn.speaker: thomas_w_jamison_iii

turn.speaker: thomas_w_jamison_iii

section.heading: Argument of E. Clinton Bamberger, Jr.

turn.speaker: e_clinton_bamberger_jr
turn.label: Mr. E. Clinton Bamberger, Jr.
turn.text: In one part of the state's argument the state assumes that the evidence --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Bamberger before you get your main argument I'd like to ask you this question.
In the event we were to affirm this judgment.
In what respect would you be in a different position?

If you go back on the question of punishment, then you were at the beginning of the trial and the reason I ask you that question is because of what occurred here on page 26 of the record and I think you were testifying at the time.

turn.speaker: e_clinton_bamberger_jr
turn.label: Mr. E. Clinton Bamberger, Jr.
turn.text: No sir I was not a Trial Counsel.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Oh, you were not, so counsel --

turn.speaker: e_clinton_bamberger_jr
turn.label: Mr. E. Clinton Bamberger, Jr.
turn.text: Yeah.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And it starts this way.
Now do you remember participating in the conference prior to Brady's trial in Judge Michelson's office?

turn.speaker: e_clinton_bamberger_jr
turn.label: Mr. E. Clinton Bamberger, Jr.
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Who was present then sir.
It was Judge Michelson, Mr. Stowes, Mr. Turk, Mr. DeBoe and myself, I think that was all.
I don't think the assistant state's attorney was there all day.
What was discussed at that conference?
Answer: quite a number of things, what we wanted to go to trial, what day we wanted to go to trial, and how we elected trial.
And I recall I stated that in view of the fact that they took a jury trial, I wanted my mine first and that the case would be limited to penalty for murder in the first-degree.
Well, why would it be limited to that penalty sir?

Answer; because there was absolutely no justification or reasons, or rhythm, or rhyme for killing a man and both of them were at least engaged in robbery or larceny which is a felony and understanding of law if both of them involved in the felony.

And there was an objection to him explaining the law and it was overruled and the witness, the counsel went on and said and both of them were in fact committing a felony, they were charged each with a greater offense and one of them committing murder which everyone of them -- it was -- would be, would automatically charge the other one with murder.
